11 North Dakota at present has one educational television
channel operating which serves only a portion of the State.
In varying stages of planning and execution aro additional
facilities which would provide a network of stations to blanket
th* entire State.
The sparse population in some areas of our Stato makes it
difficult to provide adequate funding for educational television
out of local revenues. This population pattern, however, makes
it all the more imperative that we have educational television
facilities to extend the classroom and to provide cultural
enrichment to those people who would not otherwise be exposed
to it.
Neither is North Dakota blanketed with educational radio
stations, but the reasons for its necessity are the same as
for educational television.
